intro: Selaginella simpokakensis, commonly known as the Kankens Island spikemoss, is a rare and ancient vascular plant belonging to the family Selaginellaceae. It is characterized by its small, spiky leaves and is typically found in moist, shaded environments, often in tropical or subtropical regions. This plant exhibits a unique reproductive system, producing microspores and megaspores on separate structures, a trait common among early land plants. Its morphology reflects evolutionary adaptations to arid conditions, with specialized structures for water retention. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a valuable subject for studying plant evolution and conservation.
